questions.question: When does puerperium begin?

options.C: After the fourth stage of labour

questions.question: How long does early puerperium last?
questions.explanation: Early puerperium is considered to last up to 1 week after delivery.Puerperium can be divided as follows:• Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours• Early puerperium: up to 7 days• Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days

questions.question: External os reverts back to the pre-pregnant state by how many weeks?
questions.explanation: External os never returns back to normal whereas the contour of the cervix takes 6 weeks toregain normalcy.

questions.question: Endometrial regeneration following delivery starts by which day?
questions.explanation: External os before pregnancy00External os after pregnancyOMARROW296Endometrial regeneration starts by 7th day and is completed by the 10th day. Regeneration of theepithelium at the placental site takes about 6 weeks.Endometrium regenerates from zona basalis which remains intact and is the source of newendometrium. This arises from proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and thestroma of the interglandular connective tissue.

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman has just delivered a boy by spontaneous vaginal delivery. How oftenshould her BP be recorded for the next 2 hours?
questions.explanation: For the first 2 hours following delivery, blood pressure and pulse should be recorded every 15minutes.Temperature is assessed every 4 hours for the first 8 hours after delivery.

questions.question: A woman on post-natal day 1 presented with abdominal pain which worsens when she isbreastfeeding. What is this known as?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of afterpains which are seen during puerperium.In primiparous women, the uterus tends to remain tonically contracted following delivery. Inmultiparous women, it often contracts vigorously at intervals and gives rise to afterpains, whichare similar to but milder than labor contractions.These are more pronounced as parity increases and worsen when the infant suckles, likely becauseof oxytocin release. Afterpains gradually decrease in intensity and become mild by the third day.

questions.question: What would be the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.explanation: The average duration of lochial discharge in a postpartum woman is about 24-36 days. questions.question: What is the contribution of postpartum diuresis to weight loss?
questions.explanation: Postpartum diuresis results in a relatively rapid weight loss of 2 to 3 kg.Decreased estrogen levels are associated with the diuresis of excess extracellular fluidaccumulated during pregnancy.

questions.question: A woman presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two daysafter vaginal delivery. Which nerve is likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury tothe lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexionas the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerveinvolvement.Note: The nerves most commonly injured during cesarean section are the iliohypogastric andilioinguinal nerves.

questions.question: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury?
questions.explanation: The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve causing foot drop.The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve after vaginal deliveryfollowed by femoral neuropathies.Obstetrical neuropathies are due to the pressure on branches of the lumbosacral nerve plexusduring labor. They can manifest as complaints of intense neuralgia or cramp-like pains extendingdown one or both legs as soon as the head descends into the pelvis. Footdrop can be secondary toinjury at the level of the lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve.298Injury of the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves may occur with cesarean delivery, which maymanifest as an inguinal hernia and loss of sensation at the pubic region respectively.Note: Since there are no options relating to intense neuralgia in the lower limb, foot drop becomesthe best possible answer.

questions.question: Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of
questions.explanation: Puerperal fever is defined as the temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separateoccasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24hours.In the first 24 hours, a slight rise of temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hoursare excluded while defining puerperal pyrexia.Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever and foul-smelling lochia 2 days aftervaginal delivery. Lower abdominal tenderness is elicited on examination. Her WBC count is25,000/microlitre. Which is the commonest route for the spread of her likely condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, foul-smelling lochia, and pelvic tenderness issuggestive of puerperal sepsis. The most common route of spread of this condition is directspread.Streptococcus sp. is the most important causative organism of puerperal sepsis. The commonestmanifestation is endometritis.The route of delivery is an important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis(cesarean> vaginal). The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site invaginal delivery and uterine incision in cesarean section.The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following cesarean section is administrating asingle dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of caesarean delivery.

questions.question: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother?
questions.explanation: Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for10-14 days.Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organismcausing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginningof lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple traumaoccurs due to the infant's growing teeth.Clinical features of mastitis include:•• Fever and malaise• Localized pain and tenderness299•Purulent nipple discharge• Redness and swelling of the affected breast• Positive fluctuation testA culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirmthe organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done toexclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice ofantibiotics in lactational mastitis:•Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically.• Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.• If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species thenvancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.

questions.question: A nursing mother in her third week postpartum presents with breast pain and difficulty inbreastfeeding. On examination, warmth and tenderness over the left breast are noted. Hertemperature is 38.3 °C and her WBC count is 13,000/mm3. Which of the following is falseregarding this condition?290

options.A: Most common etiological agent is streptococcus
options.B: Immediate source of infection is the infant's nose and throat

questions.explanation: The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red andswollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. The most common etiological agent isStaphylococcus aureus.Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. Symptoms usually appear in the 3rdor 4th week. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the infant's noseand throat. Predisposing factors are fissures, abrasions, and nipple cracks.Management:• Breastfeeding should be continued. If the infant is unable to nurse on the inflamed breast, themother may resort to breast pumping. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on theuninvolved breast.Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment of mastitis. Erythromycin is given to women who arepenicillin-sensitive.• If an abscess forms, surgical treatment is done.

questions.question: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she came back withfever, tachycardia, and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. What isthe most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis.Risk factors:• Pregnancy and puerperium•• Oral contraceptives• Prothrombotic conditionsMost common clinical presentation is headache with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focaldeficits.Investigations:• Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive•CT normal in 30 % of cases.-Option A: Subarachnoid hemorrhage - As there are no focal deficits, this diagnosis is unlikely.Option B: Meningitis - The patient would have presented with neck rigidity or photophobia.Moreover, the presence of early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.Option C: Acute migraine - It does not present with seizures.

questions.question: A mother, previously on OCPs, comes with her 2-week-old baby to the OPD. She informs youthat she is currently breastfeeding her child and enquires about re-starting contraception.When would you recommend she start using contraceptives?
questions.explanation: Lactating women should start using contraceptives in the 3rd postpartum month.Progesterone-only methods are the hormonal contraception of choice in a lactating mother.Efficacy of contraceptives used in postpartum period: Levonorgestrel IUD/ Implant > DMPA> Progestin-only pill.Contraception should be ideally started after the resumption of ovulation. However, there are nocontraindications for the use of contraceptives as early as 4-6 weeks in lactating women andimmediately in non-lactating women.301Lactating motherOvulation occurs after 10 weeksUse contraceptive in3rd post-partum monthNon-lactating motherOvulation occurs after 4 weeksUse contraceptive in3rd post-partum week.

questions.question: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has ahistory of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitarygland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage duringor after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency.The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increasesthe risk of infarction.Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactationfailure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency ofprolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Becausedeficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult,Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a suddenonset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases,severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.Also, it can present late with the following features:• Loss of pubic and axillary hair⚫ Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion•Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTHTreatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids,vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranialnerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carriedout. Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective.Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessiveinheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia.Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed bya prolactin level >200 µg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growthhormone secretion.

questions.question: A woman presents with fever on the 3rd postpartum day and is put on antibiotics. Fever isstill not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septicpelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her?
questions.explanation: 302Antibiotics plus heparin is the next course of treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis refers to the presence of an endovascular thrombus in the settingof associated bacterial or fungal infection.The treatment of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is broad-spectrum antibiotics plusanticoagulation. Anticoagulation is thought to prevent further thrombosis and reduce the spreadof septic emboli.303
